bestBHT.bht: At the crucifixion, even the robbers who were being crucified alongside Jesus joined in the reproaches against Him. Both robbers began to reproach Him, but one of them was later converted. This incident shows the extent to which Jesus was attacked and vilified by all, even those who were dying alongside Him. It is an aggravation of His suffering that those who should have been confessing their sins chose to add sin to sin by reproaching Him instead.

Henry Alford: Neither St. Matt. nor St. Mark is in possession of the more particular account given by St. Luke, vv. 39–48.
For the other incident which happened at this time, see John, vv. 25–27, and notes.
Albert Barnes: Or it may be that what is true of one of the criminals is by Matthew attributed to both.
The evangelists, when for the sake of brevity they avoid particularizing, often attribute to many what is said or done by single persons.
Cast the same in his teeth - This is a most unhappy translation. It means in the original simply, they upbraided him or reproached him in the same manner.
John Calvin: The two Evangelists had no other design than to show that Christ was attacked on every hand by the reproaches of all men, so that even the robbers, who were fast dying, did not spare him.
In like manner David, deploring his calamities, exhibits their violence in a strong light by saying, that he is the reproach of all sorts of men, and despised by the people.
They do not speak of particular individuals, but of the class itself.
Philip Schaff: The robbers also east the same in his teeth, or ‘cast on him the same reproaches.’
Both probably at first reproach Him, but one was afterwards converted, during the three hours they hung side by side.
At this point occurred the touching incident recorded in John 19:26-27.
Archibald T. Robertson: Even the robbers who felt a momentary superiority to Jesus thus maligned by all."
The inchoative imperfect ωνειδιζον means 'began to reproach him'.
John Gill: This was an aggravation of the sufferings of Christ, that he should be vilified by those, which were crucified with him; who ought to have been... lamenting and confessing the sins they had been guilty of, instead of adding sin to sin, and so aggravating their condemnation.
Cast the same into his teeth; as the populace, the chief priests, Scribes, elders, and Pharisees had done; twitted him with his pretensions of being the Son of God, the Messiah, and king of Israel.
Urged, that if he was, why did not he save himself, and them also?
